name: Leipzig
fun_fact: Fun fact: Leipzig's Auerbachs Keller restaurant, operating since 1530, is where Goethe set a famous scene in 'Faust' - the restaurant became so legendary from the literary reference that it's now Germany's second-most famous restaurant, with tourists and locals drinking in vaulted cellars where Mephistopheles supposedly appeared.

hero_dishes.name: Leipziger Allerlei
hero_dishes.description: Mixed vegetables (peas, carrots, asparagus, morels) in a creamy sauce, traditionally topped with crayfish. A delicate, refined vegetable dish.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Created in Leipzig in the 19th century, legend says the dish was invented to appear humble and avoid hosting expensive state guests - by highlighting vegetables over meat, Leipzig could appear less wealthy. Ironically, it's now a prized specialty requiring premium ingredients.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Barthels Hof (500+ years serving Saxon cuisine, elevated Allerlei to an art form), Auerbachs Keller (since 1530, Goethe's haunt)

hero_dishes.name: Leipziger Lerche
hero_dishes.description: Shortcrust pastry filled with marzipan, almonds, and cherries, topped with a lattice crust. Sweet, nutty, distinctly Saxon.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Originally a pastry shaped like skylarks (lerche), which were hunted near Leipzig until 1876 when the King of Saxony banned the practice. Bakers created this almond pastry as a replacement, keeping the name but saving the birds.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Traditional bakeries and cafes throughout Leipzig, served at Saxon restaurants as dessert

hero_dishes.name: Gose Beer
hero_dishes.description: Traditional Leipzig sour wheat beer brewed with coriander and salt, tart and refreshing.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Gose nearly went extinct but was revived in Leipzig in the 1980s. The Bayerischer Bahnhof brewery is the modern birthplace of Gose brewing in Leipzig, bringing back this centuries-old local style.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Bayerischer Bahnhof (modern birthplace of Gose brewing, cultural renaissance hub, serves Saxon and Bavarian cuisine)

hero_dishes.name: Saxon Quarkkeulchen
hero_dishes.description: Pan-fried potato fritters combining mashed potatoes, quark cheese, raisins, and cinnamon-sugar. Can be served sweet or savory.
hero_dishes.origin_story: A Saxon specialty found throughout the region, showing the resourcefulness of traditional cooking - transforming simple potatoes and quark into something special through technique.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Traditional Saxon restaurants, Ratskeller (opened 1904, 700 seats in new town hall basement)

signature_drinks.name: Gose Beer
signature_drinks.description: Leipzig's signature brew - sour, salty, spiced with coriander. Uniquely refreshing and polarizing.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Served at Bayerischer Bahnhof and traditional Leipzig beer halls. It's an acquired taste, but locals love the tart, salty complexity. Best enjoyed with Saxon cuisine.

signature_drinks.name: FederweiÃŸer Wine
signature_drinks.description: Young, partially fermented wine served during autumn when onion pie (Zwiebelkuchen) is in season.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: A seasonal tradition - drunk cloudy, sweet, and still fermenting, paired with Zwiebelkuchen (German onion pie). Only available in autumn when new wine is being made.

food_culture_notes: Leipzig's food reflects its history as a trade city - blending Saxon traditions with influences from across Germany
Auerbachs Keller's fame from Goethe's 'Faust' makes it a pilgrimage site for literature lovers and food enthusiasts
The city has both hearty Saxon cuisine and Michelin-starred innovation (Falco has two stars)
Gose beer revival represents Leipzig's cultural renaissance - taking historic traditions and making them contemporary

landmarks: Monument to the Battle of Nations
